title: Shandong Electric Construction Corporation III provides a 7.5 million N grant for the construction and equipment of a five-classroom block at Olorunsogo Community Primary School in 2016
description: In 2016, Shandong No. 3 Electric Construction Corporation III (SEPCO III) provides a 7.5 million N grant for the construction and equipment of a five-classroom block at Olorunsogo Community Primary School in the lfo Local Government Area (LGA) of Ogun State, Nigeria. Equipment handed over to the school included 102 reading desks and seats, 10 chairs and tables for the teachers, whiteboards for all the classrooms, 255 school bags, various items of stationery, and a graded interlocked assembly ground.   The Chinese Consulate General in Lagos coordinated the project and ISEPCO III was responsible for construction.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Shandong Electric Construction Corporation III provides a 7.5 million N grant for the construction and equipment of a five-classroom block at Olorunsogo Community Primary School in 2016

# Description
In 2016, Shandong No. 3 Electric Construction Corporation III (SEPCO III) provides a 7.5 million N grant for the construction and equipment of a five-classroom block at Olorunsogo Community Primary School in the lfo Local Government Area (LGA) of Ogun State, Nigeria. Equipment handed over to the school included 102 reading desks and seats, 10 chairs and tables for the teachers, whiteboards for all the classrooms, 255 school bags, various items of stationery, and a graded interlocked assembly ground.   The Chinese Consulate General in Lagos coordinated the project and ISEPCO III was responsible for construction.
justification: Project focuses on educational infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of school classroom block, provision of educational equipment, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese company ZTE donates 500 barrels of drinking water to Macedonia following rainstorm (Linked to projects ID#67267, ID#67269, ID#67401)
description: On August 6th, 2016, 25 thousand people were influenced by the severe rainstorm in Skopje region of Macedonia, with many facing a shortage of food, water, and electricity. Shortly after the disaster, the Macedonia branch of Chinese company ZTE donated 500 barrels of water to serve as disaster relief. Huawei (see project ID#67267) and Sinohydro (see projects ID#67269 and ID#67401) as well donated supplies, as captured by the projects linked above.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese company ZTE donates 500 barrels of drinking water to Macedonia following rainstorm (Linked to projects ID#67267, ID#67269, ID#67401)

# Description
On August 6th, 2016, 25 thousand people were influenced by the severe rainstorm in Skopje region of Macedonia, with many facing a shortage of food, water, and electricity. Shortly after the disaster, the Macedonia branch of Chinese company ZTE donated 500 barrels of water to serve as disaster relief. Huawei (see project ID#67267) and Sinohydro (see projects ID#67269 and ID#67401) as well donated supplies, as captured by the projects linked above.
justification: Project involves humanitarian aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of drinking water for disaster relief, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Sinohydro donates trucks, excavators, and sprinklers to support disaster relief efforts (Linked to Project ID#67401, #67267 and #66879)
description: On August 6th, 2016, 25 thousand people were influenced by the severe rainstorm in Skopje region. People faced a shortage of food, water, and electricity.   On August 11, 2016, the Seventh Bureau of China Water and Electric Power or Sinohydro or 中水电七局 or 中国水电七局有限公司 dispatched a total of 10 trucks, 3 excavators, and 1 sprinkler to the most severely affected villages of Singlizi, Stajkovic, and Ellington for road repairs and cleaning.   On August 12, they donated 300 blankets and 100 sets of bedding worth 4000 euros and other things to the victims (See project ID#67401).   Project ID#67267 and #66879 captured the donations with same disaster.
staff_comments: See projects #67267 and #66879 that deal with same disaster. No value of equipment sent can be found.
combined_text:

On August 12, they donated 300 blankets and 100 sets of bedding worth 4000 euros and other things to the victims (See project ID#67401). title: ICBC provides $1 billion sovereign loan to address Oman’s fiscal deficit
description: In June 2016, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and the Government of Oman, represented by the Omani Ministry of Finance, entered into a short-term loan agreement worth $1 billion (or 384.3 million OMR). The loan carried a 1 year maturity (with a loan repayment date in May 2017). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to address the deficit in the government budget caused by a decline in oil revenues.
staff_comments: 1. This loan is characterized as a ’sovereign loan’ (主权贷) in a commercial guide to Oman published by China’s Ministry of Commerce (2017年6月，阿曼获中国工商银行10亿美元主权贷款). 2. The loan’s interest rate is unknown, but given its very short maturity length, it is highly unlikely that the loan was extended on concessional terms.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL BUDGET SUPPORT

# Title
ICBC provides $1 billion sovereign loan to address Oman’s fiscal deficit

# Description
In June 2016, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and the Government of Oman, represented by the Omani Ministry of Finance, entered into a short-term loan agreement worth $1 billion (or 384.3 million OMR). The loan carried a 1 year maturity (with a loan repayment date in May 2017). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to address the deficit in the government budget caused by a decline in oil revenues.
justification: General budget support loan without specific environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Sovereign loan for fiscal deficit, no specific project or environmental focus mentioned

title: Bank of China contributes to $4 billion syndicated loan for construction of new oil and gas facilities in Oman
description: On June 29, 2016, Petroleum Development Oman (PDO or 阿曼石油开发公司) — an oil exploration and production company majority-owned by the Government of Oman — signed a $4 billion syndicated pre-export finance (PXF) facility agreement with Bank of China (BOC), HSBC Bank, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, JPMorgan, National Bank of Abu Dhabi, Natixis, Société Générale, Standard Chartered Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation. The loan had a 5-year maturity, 2-year grace period, and an interest rate of LIBOR plus 160 basis points (1.6% margin). The borrower is responsible or repaying the loan with the proceeds of the sale of crude oil.   The proceeds from the $4 billion facility were to be used by PDO to finance the construction of major new oil and gas facilities. To organize the facility, PDO worked in cooperation with Oman’s Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Oil and Gas. The facility was structured as a secured loan backed by future oil production revenues collected by an orphan special purpose vehicle based in the Netherlands, with the fund used as upfront payment to GSO for the delivery of crude oil volumes under a forward sales agreement. The deal was closed in record time – about four weeks – with banks from outside the region joining as final participants. This allowed PDO to upsize the facility from $3.4 billion to $4 billion.
staff_comments: 1. The monetary values of the contributions made by individual members of the loan syndicate are unknown. For the time being, AidData estimates Bank of China's contribution by dividing the face value of the loan ($4 billion) by the number of banks (10) that participated in the syndicate.2. The all-in interest rate that applies to the loan (2.536%) was calculated by taking the average 6-month LIBOR rate during the month (June 2016) when the loan agreement was finalized (0.936%) and adding a 1.6% margin.  3. Petroleum Development Oman is the leading exploration and production company in the Sultanate of Oman. It delivers the majority of the country's crude oil production and natural gas supply. It is jointly owned by the Government of Oman (60% equity stake), Royal Dutch Shell (34% equity stake), Total (4% equity stake), and Partex (2% equity stake).4. A pre-export finance (PXF) facility is an arrangement in which a commodity producer gets up-front cash from a customer in return for a promise to repay the customer with that commodity (possibly at a discount) in the future. PXF funds may be advanced by a lender or syndicate of lenders to a commodity producer to assist the company in meeting either its working capital needs (for example, to cover the purchase of raw materials and costs associated with processing, storage and transport) or its capital investment needs (for example, investment in plant and machinery and other elements of infrastructure). PXF facilities are usually secured by (1) an assignment of rights by the producer under an ‘offtake contract’ (i.e., a sale and purchase contract between the producer and a buyer of that producer of goods or commodities), and (2) a collection account charge over a bank account into which proceeds due to the producer from the buyer of the goods or commodities under the offtake contract are credited.  There are two key documents in prepayment finance transactions: a contract providing for the advance payment by the offtaker to the producer for the purchase of goods/commodities (the 'Prepayment Contract'), and a loan agreement between a lender and the offtaker (the 'Offtaker Loan Agreement') under which the advance payment is financed.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Bank of China contributes to $4 billion syndicated loan for construction of new oil and gas facilities in Oman

# Description
On June 29, 2016, Petroleum Development Oman (PDO or 阿曼石油开发公司) — an oil exploration and production company majority-owned by the Government of Oman — signed a $4 billion syndicated pre-export finance (PXF) facility agreement with Bank of China (BOC), HSBC Bank, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, JPMorgan, National Bank of Abu Dhabi, Natixis, Société Générale, Standard Chartered Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation. The loan had a 5-year maturity, 2-year grace period, and an interest rate of LIBOR plus 160 basis points (1.6% margin). The borrower is responsible or repaying the loan with the proceeds of the sale of crude oil.   The proceeds from the $4 billion facility were to be used by PDO to finance the construction of major new oil and gas facilities. To organize the facility, PDO worked in cooperation with Oman’s Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Oil and Gas. The facility was structured as a secured loan backed by future oil production revenues collected by an orphan special purpose vehicle based in the Netherlands, with the fund used as upfront payment to GSO for the delivery of crude oil volumes under a forward sales agreement. The deal was closed in record time – about four weeks – with banks from outside the region joining as final participants. This allowed PDO to upsize the facility from $3.4 billion to $4 billion.
justification: Primary purpose is construction of new oil and gas facilities, directly supporting fossil fuel infrastructure
evidence: Proceeds used for construction of major new oil and gas facilities, loan repayment tied to crude oil sales

title: Hanban funds the establishment of Chinese Language Teacher Program at Sultan Qaboos University
description: On September 18, 2016, the College of Arts and Sciences at Sultan Qaboos University’s College of Arts and Social Sciences launched a Chinese Language Teacher Program with support from Hanban. China's Ambassador to Oman, Yu Fulong, and the Vice-President of International Cooperation Affairs of Sultan Qaboos University (سكن عزا جامعة السلطان قابوس) attended the opening ceremony of the program. According to Ambassador Fulong, Hanban will provide a Chinese language instructor through the Confucius Institute program. The teacher will teach a class of 60 Omani students at the university.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 卡布斯苏丹大学汉语课程.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban funds the establishment of Chinese Language Teacher Program at Sultan Qaboos University

# Description
On September 18, 2016, the College of Arts and Sciences at Sultan Qaboos University’s College of Arts and Social Sciences launched a Chinese Language Teacher Program with support from Hanban. China's Ambassador to Oman, Yu Fulong, and the Vice-President of International Cooperation Affairs of Sultan Qaboos University (سكن عزا جامعة السلطان قابوس) attended the opening ceremony of the program. According to Ambassador Fulong, Hanban will provide a Chinese language instructor through the Confucius Institute program. The teacher will teach a class of 60 Omani students at the university.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Chinese Language Teacher Program, education sector focus, cultural exchange initiative

title: Oman Wangfang LLC provides 1,000 scholarships to Omani students for study in China (Linked to Project ID ID#52473)
description: On March 25, 2017, Oman Wangfang LLC agreed to sponsor 1,000 Omani students for study at Ningxia Polytechnic College in China. The program is known in Chinese as ‘宁夏职业技术学院阿曼留学生项目’ and it is part of the Chinese Ministry of Education's ‘Educational Foreign Aid Project’. Following their studies, the students are expected to return to participate in construction of the Oman-China (Duqm) Industrial Park (see Project ID#52473). The program of study is based on a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed between Oman Wangfang LLC and Ningxia Polytechnic College in May 2016.   Omani students are to be instructed in petrochemical engineering, construction, computer software, technology, renewable energy, petroleum equipment, and economic management as well as Chinese. According to the Oman News Agency, 75% of the course is comprised of academic training and the remaining 25% of the course is vocational training (via internships). According to Ningxia Polytechnic College, the program is tailor made to the needs of the Omani students and Chinese enterprises operating in Oman. The first batch of 39 students completed their training in July 2017, and the second batch was expected to leave China shortly thereafter.
staff_comments: Oman Wangfang LLC is owned by the Chinese Government.  Although Oman Wangfang LLC announced its pledge in March 2017, it appears that the program began in 2016. Oman was not ODA-eligible from 2011 onwards.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Oman Wangfang LLC provides 1,000 scholarships to Omani students for study in China (Linked to Project ID ID#52473)

# Description
On March 25, 2017, Oman Wangfang LLC agreed to sponsor 1,000 Omani students for study at Ningxia Polytechnic College in China. The program is known in Chinese as ‘宁夏职业技术学院阿曼留学生项目’ and it is part of the Chinese Ministry of Education's ‘Educational Foreign Aid Project’. Following their studies, the students are expected to return to participate in construction of the Oman-China (Duqm) Industrial Park (see Project ID#52473). The program of study is based on a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed between Oman Wangfang LLC and Ningxia Polytechnic College in May 2016.   Omani students are to be instructed in petrochemical engineering, construction, computer software, technology, renewable energy, petroleum equipment, and economic management as well as Chinese. According to the Oman News Agency, 75% of the course is comprised of academic training and the remaining 25% of the course is vocational training (via internships). According to Ningxia Polytechnic College, the program is tailor made to the needs of the Omani students and Chinese enterprises operating in Oman. The first batch of 39 students completed their training in July 2017, and the second batch was expected to leave China shortly thereafter.
justification: Project focuses on education and human capital development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarship program for Omani students, focus on academic and vocational training in various fields including renewable energy, but primarily an educational initiative

title: ICBC participates in $330 million syndicated loan with Majan Electricity Company (MJEC) for general corporate purposes (Linked to Project ID#96402)
description: In April 2016, Majan Electricity Company (MJEC) — a subsidiary of Oman’s Electricity Holding Company S.A.O.C. (EHC) that manages power networks in some of Oman's regions — signed a $330 million syndicated loan agreement with a set of Chinese and non-Chinese banks for general corporate purposes.  Participants in the loan syndicate included Arab Banking Corporation, Arab Petroleum Investments Corporation, Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank, Ahli United Bank, Ahli Bank Oman, Export Development Canada, National Commercial Bank, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Union National Bank, Bank of Bahrain and Kuwait, Bank of China, and Al Khaliji Commercial Bank. ICBC's contribution to the syndicate is captured via Project ID#96401. Bank of China's contribution is captured via Project ID#96402.  JP Morgan and Bank Muscat Investment Banking served as mandated lead arrangers. The loan carries a 10-year maturity (final maturity date: 2026) and an estimated interest rate of LIBOR plus a 3.5% margin.
staff_comments: 1. AidData has estimated the all-in interest rate by adding 3.5% to average 6-month LIBOR in April 2016 (0.903%). 2. The exact monetary value of ICBC and Bank of China's contributions to the $330 million syndicated loan tranche are unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes equal contributions ($27,500,000) across the 12 known members of the syndicate. 3. EHC is also known as Nama Holding. 4. The Electricity Holding Company S.A.O.C. (EHC) is a closed joint stock company registered under the Commercial Companies Law of Oman on 19/10/2002 and commenced business on 16/9/2003. EHC is wholly owned by the Government of The Sultanate of Oman. 5. Dentons served as a legal adviser to the borrower. Latham & Watkins, Al Busaidy, Mansoor Jamal & Co served as legal advisors to the Joint Lead Managers. 6. In December 2019, State Grid International Development Co., Limited (SGID), the sole platform for overseas investments and operations of the State Grid Corporation of China, acquired a 49% stake in Oman Electricity Transmission Company (OETC) from Electricity Holding Company S.A.O.C. (also known as Nama Holding) for approximately $1 billion.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
ICBC participates in $330 million syndicated loan with Majan Electricity Company (MJEC) for general corporate purposes (Linked to Project ID#96402)

# Description
In April 2016, Majan Electricity Company (MJEC) — a subsidiary of Oman’s Electricity Holding Company S.A.O.C. (EHC) that manages power networks in some of Oman's regions — signed a $330 million syndicated loan agreement with a set of Chinese and non-Chinese banks for general corporate purposes.  Participants in the loan syndicate included Arab Banking Corporation, Arab Petroleum Investments Corporation, Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank, Ahli United Bank, Ahli Bank Oman, Export Development Canada, National Commercial Bank, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Union National Bank, Bank of Bahrain and Kuwait, Bank of China, and Al Khaliji Commercial Bank. ICBC's contribution to the syndicate is captured via Project ID#96401. Bank of China's contribution is captured via Project ID#96402.  JP Morgan and Bank Muscat Investment Banking served as mandated lead arrangers. The loan carries a 10-year maturity (final maturity date: 2026) and an estimated interest rate of LIBOR plus a 3.5% margin.
justification: Loan for general corporate purposes without specific environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: Syndicated loan for general corporate purposes, no specific project details provided
